INFO.name: QUERY
INFO.value: select * from ivoa.obscore WHERE (INTERSECTS(CIRCLE('ICRS',1.0,1.0,1.0), s_region) = 1) AND science_observation='T' AND data_rights='hoooooo'

FIELD.name: collections
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Indicates that there are external products

FIELD.name: o_ucd
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: UCD describing the observable axis (pixel values)

FIELD.name: obs_publisher_did
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: publisher dataset identifier

FIELD.name: obs_collection
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: short name for the data collection

FIELD.name: facility_name
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: telescope name

FIELD.name: instrument_name
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: instrument name

FIELD.name: obs_id
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: internal dataset identifier

FIELD.name: dataproduct_type
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: type of product

FIELD.name: calib_level
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: calibration level (2 or 3). 2 if product_type = MOUS, 3 if product_type = GOUS

FIELD.name: target_name
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: name of intended target

FIELD.name: s_ra
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: RA of central coordinates

FIELD.name: s_dec
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: DEC of central coordinates

FIELD.name: s_fov
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: size of the region covered (~diameter of minimum bounding circle)

FIELD.name: s_region
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: region bounded by observation

FIELD.name: s_xel1
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Number of elements along the first spatial axis

FIELD.name: s_xel2
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Number of elements along the second spatial axis

FIELD.name: em_xel
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Number of elements along the spectral axis

FIELD.name: t_xel
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Number of elements along the time axis

FIELD.name: pol_xel
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Number of polarization samples

FIELD.name: s_resolution
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: typical spatial resolution

FIELD.name: t_min
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: start time of observation (MJD)

FIELD.name: t_max
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: end time of observation (MJD)

FIELD.name: t_exptime
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: exposure time of observation

FIELD.name: t_resolution
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: typical temporal resolution

FIELD.name: em_min
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: start spectral coordinate value

FIELD.name: em_max
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: stop spectral coordinate value

FIELD.name: em_res_power
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: typical spectral resolution

FIELD.name: pol_states
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: polarization states present in the data

FIELD.name: access_url
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: URL to download the data

FIELD.name: access_format
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Content format of the data

FIELD.name: access_estsize
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Estimated size of datasets in kilobytes

FIELD.name: proposal_id
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Identifier of proposal to which NO observation belongs.

FIELD.name: data_rights
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Access to data.

FIELD.name: gal_longitude
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Galactic longitude of the observation for RA/Dec. Estimated using PyEphem and RA/Dec.

FIELD.name: gal_latitude
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Galactic latitude of the observation for RA/Dec. Estimated using PyEphem and RA/Dec.

FIELD.name: band_list
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Space delimited list of bands

FIELD.name: em_resolution
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Estimated frequency resolution from all the spectral windows, using median values of channel widths.

FIELD.name: bandwidth
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Total Bandwidth

FIELD.name: antenna_arrays
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Blank-separated list of Pad:Antenna pairs, i.e., A109:DV09 J504:DV02 J505:DV05 for antennas DV09, DV02 and DV05 sitting on pads A109, J504, and J505, respectively.

FIELD.name: is_mosaic
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Flag to indicate if this ASDM represents a mosaic or not.

FIELD.name: obs_release_date
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: timestamp of date the data becomes publicly available

FIELD.name: spatial_resolution
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Average of the maximum and minimum spatial resolution values of all spectral windows

FIELD.name: frequency_support
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: All frequency ranges used by the field

FIELD.name: frequency
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Observed (tuned) reference frequency on the sky.

FIELD.name: velocity_resolution
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Estimated velocity resolution from all the spectral windows, from frequency resolution.

FIELD.name: obs_creator_name
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: case-insensitive partial match over the full PI name. Wildcards can be used

FIELD.name: pub_title
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Case insensitive search through the title of the publication.

FIELD.name: first_author
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: The first author as provided by telbib.eso.org.

FIELD.name: authors
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Full list of first author and all co-authors

FIELD.name: pub_abstract
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Case insensitive text search through the abstract of the publication.

FIELD.name: publication_year
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: The year the publication did appear in the printed version of the refereed journal.

FIELD.name: proposal_abstract
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Text search on the proposal abstract. Only abstracts will be returned which contain the given text. The search is case-insensitive.

FIELD.name: schedblock_name
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Name of the Scheduling Block used as a template for executing the ASDM containing this Field.

FIELD.name: proposal_authors
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Full name of CoIs .

FIELD.name: sensitivity_10kms
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Estimated noise in an nominal 10km/s bandwidth. Note this is an indication only, it does not include the effects of flagging or Hanning smoothing, and a 10km/s bandwidth may not be achievable with the data as taken.

FIELD.name: cont_sensitivity_bandwidth
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Estimated noise in the aggregated continuum bandwidth. Note this is an indication only, it does not include the effects of flagging or dynamic range limitations.

FIELD.name: pwv
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Estimated precipitable water vapour from the XML_CALWVR_ENTITIES table.

FIELD.name: group_ous_uid
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Group OUS ID

FIELD.name: member_ous_uid
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Member OUS ID

FIELD.name: asdm_uid
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: UID of the ASDM containing this Field.

FIELD.name: obs_title
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Case-insensitive search over the project title

FIELD.name: type
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Type flags.

FIELD.name: scan_intent
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Scan intent list for the observed field.

FIELD.name: science_observation
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Flag to indicate whether this is a science observation.

FIELD.name: spatial_scale_max
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Due to the fact that radio antennas can not be placed infinitely close, measurements do have a smallest separation which translates into a maximal angular distance beyond which features can not be resolved reliably any more. Adding observations with the ALMA Total Power array can add those missing largest scales.

FIELD.name: qa2_passed
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Quality Assessment 2 status: does the Member / Group OUS fulfil the PI's requirements?

FIELD.name: bib_reference
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Bibliography code

FIELD.name: lastModified
FIELD.DESCRIPTION: Time stamp of last modification of the metadata

TR.TD: [92.00..93.99GHz,31250.00kHz,557.8uJy/beam@10km/s,22uJy/beam@native, XX YY] U [93.94..95.92GHz,31250.00kHz,553.3uJy/beam@10km/s,22uJy/beam@native, XX YY] U [104.00..105.99GHz,31250.00kHz,550.2uJy/beam@10km/s,23uJy/beam@native, XX YY] U [106.00..107.99GHz,31250.00kHz,557.7uJy/beam@10km/s,23.6uJy/beam@native, XX YY]

A Publicly Available Multiobservatory Data Set of an Enhanced Network Patch from the Photosphere to the Corona Spatio-Temporal Comparisons of the Hydrogen-Alpha Line Width and ALMA 3 mm Brightness Temperature in the Weak Solar Network Subterahertz radius and limb brightening of the Sun derived from SST and ALMA The Solar ALMA Science Archive (SALSA). First release, SALAT, and FITS header standard The Subterahertz Solar Cycle: Polar and Equatorial Radii Derived from SST and ALMA The quiet sun at mm wavelengths as seen by ALMA
Alissandrakis, Costas E. Henriques, Vasco M. J. Kobelski, Adam R. Menezes, Fabian Tarr, Lucas A.

Alissandrakis, Costas E.; Bastian, T. S.; Brajša, Roman Henriques, Vasco M. J.; Jafarzadeh, Shahin; Guevara Gómez, Juan Camilo; Eklund, Henrik; Wedemeyer, Sven; Szydlarski, Mikołaj; Haugan, Stein Vidar H.; Mohan, Atul Kobelski, Adam R.; Tarr, Lucas A.; Jaeggli, Sarah A.; Luber, Nicholas; Warren, Harry P.; Savage, Sabrina Menezes, Fabian; Selhorst, Caius L.; Giménez de Castro, Carlos Guillermo; Valio, Adriana Tarr, Lucas A.; Kobelski, Adam R.; Jaeggli, Sarah A.; Molnar, Momchil; Cauzzi, Gianna; Reardon, Kevin P.

At subterahertz frequencies—i.e., millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths—there is a gap in measurements of the solar radius, as well as other parameters of the solar atmosphere. As the observational wavelength changes, the radius varies because the altitude of the dominant electromagnetic radiation is produced at different heights in the solar atmosphere. Moreover, radius variations throughout long time series are indicative of changes in the solar atmosphere that may be related to the solar cycle. Therefore, the solar radius is an important parameter for the calibration of solar atmospheric models enabling a better understanding of the atmospheric structure. In this work, we use data from the Solar Submillimeter-wave Telescope (SST) and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) at frequencies of 100, 212, 230, and 405 GHz to measure the equatorial and polar radii of the Sun. The radii measured with extensive data from the SST agree with the radius-versus-frequency trend present in the literature. The radii derived from ALMA maps at 230 GHz also agree with the radius-versus-frequency trend, whereas the 100 GHz radii are slightly above the values reported by other authors. In addition, we analyze the equatorial and polar radius behavior over the years by determining the correlation coefficient between solar activity and subterahertz radius time series at 212 and 405 GHz (SST). The variations of the SST-derived radii over 13 yr are correlated to the solar activity when considering equatorial regions of the solar atmosphere and anticorrelated when considering polar regions. The ALMA-derived radius time series for 100 and 230 GHz show very similar behaviors with those of SST. ...(5)

ALMA offers a truly unique insight into the Sun by providing a linear thermometer into the chromosphere. These layers of the chromosphere are largely unstudied or have been muddled by line-of-sight effects common to optically thin measurements. Here we intend to use the advantages of ALMA in order to study one of the most readily available signatures of magnetic reconnection, microflares, in the chromosphere: the region through which the energy and plasma must flow to get into the corona. By observing the statistics of microflaring in two wavelengths, we will be able to better constrain the heights and dynamics of energy transfer in the chromosphere during magnetic reconnection.
Jaeggli, Sarah; Savage, Sabrina; Tarr, Lucas;
Microflares in the Chromosphere with ALMA

In this work, we use data from the Solar Submillimeter-wave Telescope (SST) and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) at frequencies of 100, 212, 230, and 405 GHz to measure the equatorial and polar radii of the Sun. The radii measured with extensive data from the SST agree with the radius-versus-frequency trend present in the literature. The radii derived from ALMA maps at 230 GHz also agree with the radius-versus-frequency trend, whereas the 100 GHz radii are slightly above the values reported by other authors. In addition, we analyze the equatorial and polar radius behavior over the years by determining the correlation coefficient between solar activity and subterahertz radius time series at 212 and 405 GHz (SST). The variations of the SST-derived radii over 13 yr are correlated to the solar activity when considering equatorial regions of the solar atmosphere and anticorrelated when considering polar regions. The ALMA-derived radius time series for 100 and 230 GHz show very similar behaviors with those of SST. ...(5)

ALMA offers a truly unique insight into the Sun by providing a linear thermometer into the chromosphere. These layers of the chromosphere are largely unstudied or have been muddled by line-of-sight effects common to optically thin measurements. Here we intend to use the advantages of ALMA in order to study one of the most readily available signatures of magnetic reconnection, microflares, in the chromosphere: the region through which the energy and plasma must flow to get into the corona. By observing the statistics of microflaring in two wavelengths, we will be able to better constrain the heights and dynamics of energy transfer in the chromosphere during magnetic reconnection.
Jaeggli, Sarah; Savage, Sabrina; Tarr, Lucas;
Microflares in the Chromosphere with ALMA

Alissandrakis, Costas E. Henriques, Vasco M. J. Kobelski, Adam R. Menezes, Fabian Tarr, Lucas A.

Alissandrakis, Costas E.; Bastian, T. S.; Brajša, Roman Henriques, Vasco M. J.; Jafarzadeh, Shahin; Guevara Gómez, Juan Camilo; Eklund, Henrik; Wedemeyer, Sven; Szydlarski, Mikołaj; Haugan, Stein Vidar H.; Mohan, Atul Kobelski, Adam R.; Tarr, Lucas A.; Jaeggli, Sarah A.; Luber, Nicholas; Warren, Harry P.; Savage, Sabrina Menezes, Fabian; Selhorst, Caius L.; Giménez de Castro, Carlos Guillermo; Valio, Adriana Tarr, Lucas A.; Kobelski, Adam R.; Jaeggli, Sarah A.; Molnar, Momchil; Cauzzi, Gianna; Reardon, Kevin P.

At subterahertz frequencies—i.e., millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths—there is a gap in measurements of the solar radius, as well as other parameters of the solar atmosphere. As the observational wavelength changes, the radius varies because the altitude of the dominant electromagnetic radiation is produced at different heights in the solar atmosphere. Moreover, radius variations throughout long time series are indicative of changes in the solar atmosphere that may be related to the solar cycle. Therefore, the solar radius is an important parameter for the calibration of solar atmospheric models enabling a better understanding of the atmospheric structure. In this work, we use data from the Solar Submillimeter-wave Telescope (SST) and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) at frequencies of 100, 212, 230, and 405 GHz to measure the equatorial and polar radii of the Sun. The radii measured with extensive data from the SST agree with the radius-versus-frequency trend present in the literature. The radii derived from ALMA maps at 230 GHz also agree with the radius-versus-frequency trend, whereas the 100 GHz radii are slightly above the values reported by other authors. In addition, we analyze the equatorial and polar radius behavior over the years by determining the correlation coefficient between solar activity and subterahertz radius time series at 212 and 405 GHz (SST). The variations of the SST-derived radii over 13 yr are correlated to the solar activity when considering equatorial regions of the solar atmosphere and anticorrelated when considering polar regions. The ALMA-derived radius time series for 100 and 230 GHz show very similar behaviors with those of SST. ...(5)

ALMA offers a truly unique insight into the Sun by providing a linear thermometer into the chromosphere. These layers of the chromosphere are largely unstudied or have been muddled by line-of-sight effects common to optically thin measurements. Here we intend to use the advantages of ALMA in order to study one of the most readily available signatures of magnetic reconnection, microflares, in the chromosphere: the region through which the energy and plasma must flow to get into the corona. By observing the statistics of microflaring in two wavelengths, we will be able to better constrain the heights and dynamics of energy transfer in the chromosphere during magnetic reconnection.
Jaeggli, Sarah; Savage, Sabrina; Tarr, Lucas;
Microflares in the Chromosphere with ALMA

At subterahertz frequencies—i.e., millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths—there is a gap in measurements of the solar radius, as well as other parameters of the solar atmosphere. As the observational wavelength changes, the radius varies because the altitude of the dominant electromagnetic radiation is produced at different heights in the solar atmosphere. The radii derived from ALMA maps at 230 GHz also agree with the radius-versus-frequency trend, whereas the 100 GHz radii are slightly above the values reported by other authors. The variations of the SST-derived radii over 13 yr are correlated to the solar activity when considering equatorial regions of the solar atmosphere and anticorrelated when considering polar regions. The ALMA-derived radius time series for 100 and 230 GHz show very similar behaviors with those of SST. ...(5)

ALMA offers a truly unique insight into the Sun by providing a linear thermometer into the chromosphere. These layers of the chromosphere are largely unstudied or have been muddled by line-of-sight effects common to optically thin measurements. Here we intend to use the advantages of ALMA in order to study one of the most readily available signatures of magnetic reconnection, microflares, in the chromosphere: the region through which the energy and plasma must flow to get into the corona. By observing the statistics of microflaring in two wavelengths, we will be able to better constrain the heights and dynamics of energy transfer in the chromosphere during magnetic reconnection.
